facts.text: On August 3, 1953, Government of West Bengal referred industrial dispute between appellant company and its workmen under s. 10 of Industrial Disputes Act to Second Industrial Tribunal.

During pendency of reference, on October 6, 1953, workmen surrounded and confined E. L. D'Cruz, acting Works Manager, in factory premises from 9:15 a.m. to 2:15 p.m. over dispute on Puja bonus payment.

Same day, workmen went on strike at 9:15 a.m.; D'Cruz called them to resume work; they refused; company issued notices at 9:45 a.m. and 10:45 a.m. to resume; after police arrival, company declared lock-out; some workmen arrested.
Company served charge-sheets on workmen requiring explanations within 24 hours; workmen submitted explanations; enquiry held; workmen found guilty of gross misconduct meriting dismissal.

On October 31, 1953, company applied under s. 33 ID Act to Tribunal for permission to dismiss 170 workmen effective October 6, 1953 (Cal. Nos. 518, 519, 557 of 1953); later withdrew against many, continued against 67; one died, two resigned, leaving 64.

Workmen denied offence, receipt of charge-sheets, enquiry; pleaded illegal lock-out, violation of natural justice; Tribunal granted permission to dismiss 3 workmen (Subbas Roy, Madhusudhan Rout, Bimal Kumar Ghose); refused for rest due to doubt on identity/complicity.
Tribunal held prima facie case made out, company acted bona fide, no discrimination/vindictiveness; took back majority after regret expressed.
On January 8, 1954, workmen applied under s. 33A ID Act; allowed July 2, 1954.

Appeals filed: company against s.33 orders, workmen against dismissal of 3; on March 29, 1955, Labour Appellate Tribunal (LAT) dismissed company appeals under s.33 and workmen appeal, upholding 3 dismissals; set aside s.33A order as misconceived.

On April 20, 1955, company initiated fresh proceedings against 64 workmen: sent registered notices to registered addresses, affixed notices on notice boards inside/outside premises (remained till June 9, 1955); notices to 2-24 returned unserved.
April 28, 1955: company informed Labour Commissioner of offences and proposed action.
May 20, 1955: company wrote to Workers' Union secretary for addresses of unserved workmen; no reply.
Enquiry terminated June 9, 1955; services of 64 workmen terminated June 22, 1955.

August 8, 1955: West Bengal Govt referred dispute on dismissal of 64 workmen under s.10 ID Act: justified? Reinstate? Compensation for action/enforced idleness from 6-10-53? Awards implemented? Compensation for non-implementation.
16 workmen resigned; Haroo Haldar pleaded guilty; continued against 47 workmen.

Sixth Industrial Tribunal award June 7, 1956: Nos. 2-24 not properly served, reinstate from April 1, 1955 with back wages etc.; upheld dismissal Nos. 25-48 (identity established, no bias); strike illegal, no compensation pre-March 29, 1955; back wages for 2-24 from April 1, 1955.

Appeals to LAT: Union and company; September 11, 1956 LAT dismissed company appeal, allowed Union: rejected D'Cruz evidence, no other proof, management decision perverse; set aside permission/dismissal for 25-48.
LAT amended order September 28, 1956: set aside IT award confirming discharge of 24 workmen; ordered reinstatement of 24 with back wages from April 1, 1955.

legal_issues.text: Whether the dismissal of the 47 workmen was justified.
Whether Labour Appellate Tribunal could interfere with management's enquiry findings as if sitting in appeal.
Whether notice of enquiry was properly served on workmen Nos. 2-24.
Whether s.33 proceedings operate as res judicata barring fresh enquiry.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appeal to LAT by Union incompetent as no question of law involved.
LAT cannot sit in appeal against managerial enquiry; Tribunal interferes only for want of good faith, victimisation, unfair practice, basic error/violation of natural justice, or perverse finding.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen; Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Pt. Ram Sarup

petitioner_arguments.text: Notice properly served per standing orders (affixed notice boards inside/outside, registered post, informed Union/Labour Commissioner); no violation of natural justice.
Strike illegal; lock-out justified; s.33 permission proceedings do not bar fresh enquiry/dismissal post-ban lift.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.33, s.10 Industrial Disputes Act; no res judicata

respondent_arguments.text: No proper notice served on Nos. 2-24; affixing notices insufficient due to lock-out; should have sent to Union or advertised.
No second enquiry possible; s.33 findings confirmed by LAT operate as res judicata.
Basic errors in IT award: e.g., numbers don't match (170 proceeded, 106 reinstated?); LAT rightly interfered.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen

respondent_arguments.text: Workmen entitled to compensation for enforced idleness.

court_reasoning.text: LAT erred by sitting in appeal over managerial enquiry, rejecting D'Cruz evidence without basis; misapprehended proceedings as under s.33/33A instead of s.10 reference.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal does not substitute judgment unless good faith wanting, victimisation, basic error, natural justice violation, or perverse finding.

court_reasoning.text: Managerial enquiry not vitiated; complied with standing orders on notice (affixed boards outside gate accessible during lock-out, registered post, Union/Labour Commissioner informed); no natural justice infraction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Workmen cannot evade by not providing addresses or checking notice boards.

court_reasoning.text: s.33 proceedings prima facie only, to lift ban during pendency; no adjudication of dispute, no res judicata for s.10 reference.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Permission under s.33 does not bar subsequent dispute adjudication.

court_reasoning.text: No basic error: parties proceeded on basis of 67/64 workmen; strike illegal, lock-out justified, no compensation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Identity/misconduct established by evidence acceptable to IT.

holdings.text: Industrial Tribunal/LAT can interfere with management enquiry only if want of good faith, victimisation/unfair practice, basic error/natural justice violation, or perverse finding.
Dismissals of all 47 workmen justified; no proper notice finding erroneous; no res judicata from s.33; no compensation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Indian Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Principles governing Tribunal interference with management enquiry.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Pt. Ram Sarup
precedents_cited.relevance: No interference if fair enquiry, illegal strike, no natural justice violation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Buckingham and Carnatic Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: LAT referred to principles on evidence.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hanuman Jute Mills v. Amin Das
precedents_cited.relevance: No appeal if Tribunal examined bona fides, no unfair practice.

precedents_cited.case_name: Atherton West Co. Ltd. v. Suti Mill Mazdoor Union
precedents_cited.relevance: s.33 does not bar industrial dispute.

precedents_cited.case_name: Automobile Products of India Ltd. v. Rukmaji Bala
precedents_cited.relevance: s.33/22 only for permission, no adjudication/res judicata.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference of disputes; permission for dismissal during pendency; special application for contravention; illegal strike definition.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes (Appellate Tribunal) Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Permission to dismiss during appeal pendency.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; LAT orders dated September 11/28, 1956 and IT award June 7, 1956 as to workmen Nos. 2-24 set aside; dismissals of all 47 workmen upheld; claim for compensation disallowed.
outcome.relief_granted: None to workmen; employer's action affirmed.

key_quotes.text: Undoubtedly, the management of a concern has power to direct its own internal administration and discipline but the power, is not unlimited and when a dispute arises, Industrial Tribunals have been given the power to see whether the termination of service of a workman is justified and to give appropriate relief.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of Tribunal power over management decisions.

key_quotes.text: It will interfere (i) when there is want of good faith, (ii) when there is victimisation or unfair labour practice, (iii) when the management has been guilty of a basic error or violation of a principle of natural justice, and (iv) when on the materials, the finding is completely baseless or perverse.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Four grounds for Tribunal interference quoted from precedent.

key_quotes.text: No order of dismissal shall be made unless the worker concerned is informed and given opportunity of explaining the circumstances alleged against him, but to avail himself of this privilege such worker must attend before the management when directed to do so. Service... by fixing the same on the Company's Notice Board.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Standing order justifying notice service method upheld.
